facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 618 of 1964 before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 618 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated November 29, 1960 of Madras High Court in Appeal Suit No. 207 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated November 29, 1960 of the Madras High Court in Appeal Suit No. 207 of 1957.

facts.text: Rangaswami Chettiar was a man of considerable property and lived in Poolathur village.

anchor.surface_text: One Rangaswami Chettiar was a man of companysiderable property and used to live in Poolathur village.

facts.text: Rangaswami Chettiar first married Bappini and had a son by her, but both died.

anchor.surface_text: He first married one Bappini and had a son by her. But both the son and Bappani died.

facts.text: Rangaswami Chettiar married Ammathayee, who was defendant No. 2 and appellant No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: He therefore married Ammathayee, who was defendant No. 2 in the suit and is appellant No. I before us.

facts.text: Rangaswami Chettiar had a son and two daughters by Ammathayee, all three died.

anchor.surface_text: He had a son and two daughters by her. But unfortunately all the three children died.

facts.text: Rangaswami Chettiar married Lakshmiammal in 1943, she was first defendant.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter Rangaswami Chettiar married Lakshmiammal in 1943. She was the first defendant in the suit.

facts.text: No child born to Lakshmiammal for about three years after marriage to Rangaswami Chettiar.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that numberchild was born to Lakshmiammal for about three years and therefore Rangaswami Chettiar married a fourth time.

facts.text: Rangaswami Chettiar's fourth wife was sister of his second wife named Supputhayee.

anchor.surface_text: His fourth wife was the sister of his second wife named Supputhayee.

facts.text: Lakshmiammal gave birth to a son in February 1949.

anchor.surface_text: In February 1949 Lakshmiammal gave birth to a son.

facts.text: Dispute whether Lakshmiammal left husband about 1945 due to quarrels.

anchor.surface_text: There is dispute as to the question whether Lakshmiammal had left her husband about 1945 or so because of frequent quarrels between the two.

facts.text: Fourth wife had no children.

anchor.surface_text: Anyhow the fourth wife had also numberchildren.

facts.text: Rangaswami Chettiar fell ill in June 1953, treated at Batlagundu hospital.

anchor.surface_text: In June 1953 Rangaswami Chettiar fell ill. He was first treated as an out-patient in Batlagundu hospital and later admitted as an in-patient.

facts.text: On June 16, 1953 Rangaswami Chettiar executed registered deed of gift to Ammathayee of immovable joint family property.

anchor.surface_text: On June 16, 1953 he executed a registered deed of gift in favour of his second wife Ammathayee of certain immovable joint family property.

facts.text: Lakshmiammal published notice accusing second and fourth wife, claiming gift deed not valid.

anchor.surface_text: Lakshmiammal when she came to know of this gift published a numberice in a newspaper accusing the second and fourth wife of trying to deprive her and her minor son of their due share in the joint family property by having the gift deed executed and claimed that the gift deed was number valid.

facts.text: On September 4, 1953 Rangaswami Chettiar sent notice in reply denying paternity of son born to Lakshmiammal.

anchor.surface_text: On September 4, 1953, Rangaswami Chettiar sent a numberice in reply to the numberice published by Lakshmiammal. Ili that numberice Rangaswami Chettiar accused Lakshmiammal of having left Wm a year and a half after the marriage after quarrelling with him. He also accused her of living a life of promiscuity thereafter. Finally he said in the numberice that the son born to Lakshmiammal in Feb-ruary 1949 was number his son.

facts.text: On September 15, 1953 Lakshmiammal replied maintaining son was Rangaswami Chettiar's.

anchor.surface_text: Lakshmiammal gave a reply to this numberice of Rangasmami Chettiar on September 15, 1953, in which she maintained that the child was Rangaswami Chettiars.

facts.text: Rangaswami Chettiar died in December 1953.

anchor.surface_text: In, December 1963 Rangaswami Chettiar died.

facts.text: Suit filed on January 3, 1955 by minor son claiming half share in joint family properties.

anchor.surface_text: The present suit was filed a year later on January 3, 1955 on behalf of the minor son. He claimed half share in the joint family properties left by Rangaswami Chettiar.

facts.text: Defendants Nos. 1, 2 and 3 are three widows who between them have half share.

anchor.surface_text: To this suit the three widows who between them have half share were defendants Nos. 1, 2 and 3.

facts.text: Main defence of step-mothers: plaintiff not son of Rangaswami Chettiar.

anchor.surface_text: The main defence of the two step-mothers, who are number appel- lants before us, was that the, plaintiff though born to Lakshmiammal was number the son of Rangaswami Chettiar and was therefore number entitled to any share in his properties.

facts.text: Ammathayee pleaded gift deed valid.

anchor.surface_text: Further Ammathayee pleaded that the gift deed in her favour was valid and that even if the plaintiff was the son of Rangaswami Chettiar he would be entitled to half share of the properties other than those gifted to her by R angaswami Chettiar before his death.

facts.text: Trial court found plaintiff son of Rangaswami Chettiar and gift invalid.

anchor.surface_text: On the main question, namely whether the plaintiff was the son of Rangaswami Chettiar, the trial companyrt found in his favour. Further on the question whether the gift deed in favour of Ammathayee was valid, the trial companyrt was of opinion that it was number companypetent for Rangaswami Chettiar to make a gift of immovable joint family property to his wife. The trial companyrt therefore held the gift to be invalid

facts.text: High Court upheld trial court findings on paternity and gift validity.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court however upheld both the findings. On a companysideration of the evidence, the High Court came. to the companyclusion that the heavy burden that lay on those who disputed the paternity of the plaintiff-respondent in view of s. 112 of the Indian Evidence Act, No. 1 of 1872, had number been discharged in this case

facts.text: Supreme Court holds plaintiff is legitimate son of Rangaswami Chettiar.

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore numberhesitation in agreeing with the High Court, particularly taking into account the evidence of Lakshmiammal which has number been disbelieved by the High Court, that the appellants had companypletely failed to prove number- access of Rangaswami Chettiar to Lakshmiammal at any time when the plaintiff-respondent companyld have been begotten. In these circumstances there is numberreason for us to interfere with the companycurrent finding of fact as to the paternity of the plaintiff-respondent and we hold that he is the legitimate son of Rangaswami Chettiar.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds gift deed to Ammathayee invalid under Hindu law.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the donee-appellant that the gift in her favour by her husband of ancestral immovable property made out of affection should be upheld must therefore fail, for numbersuch gift is permitted under Hindu Law insofar as immovable ancestral property is companycerned.

On a consideration of the evidence, the High Court came to the conclusion that the heavy burden that lay on those who disputed the paternity of the plaintiff-respondent in view of s. 112 of the Indian Evidence Act, No. 1 of 1872, had not been discharged in this case

anchor.surface_text: Section 112 is in these terms- The fact that any person was born during the continuance of a valid marriage between his mother and any man, or within two hundred and eighty days after its dissolution, the mother remaining unmarried, shall be conclusive proof that he is the legitimate son of that man, unless it can be shown that the parties to the marriage had noaccess to each other at any time when he could have been begotten.

concepts.interpretation: Conclusive presumption rebuttable only by proof of non-access at time of possible conception

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: donee-appellant that the gift in her favour by her husband of ancestral immovable property made out of affection should be upheld must therefore fail

concepts.unlisted_description: Presumption of legitimacy for child born during valid marriage unless non-access proved

concepts.interpretation: Supreme Court ordinarily does not interfere with concurrent findings of lower courts

Gifts to daughter-in-law in token of love permitted as stridhan, but not ancestral immovable property

anchor.surface_text: On June 16, 1953 he executed a registered deed of gift in favour of his second wife Ammathayee of certain immovable joint family property.

issues.text: whether the plaintiff-respondent was the son of Rangaswami Chettiar

anchor.surface_text: The two main questions which have been argued before us are- whether the plaintiff-respondent was the son of Rangaswami Chettiar, and whether the deed of gift was valid.

issues.text: whether the deed of gift was valid

anchor.surface_text: The two main questions which have been argued before us are- whether the plaintiff-respondent was the son of Rangaswami Chettiar, and whether the deed of gift was valid. So far as the first question is concerned, there is a concurrent finding of the trial court as well as of the High Court that the plaintiffrespondent is the son of Rangaswami Chettiar.

issues.text: whether the plaintiff was the son of Rangaswami Chettiar

anchor.surface_text: On the main question, namely whether the plaintiff was the son of Rangaswami Chettiar, the trial court found in his favour. Further on the question whether the gift deed in favour of Ammathayee was valid, the trial court was of opinion that it was not competent for Rangaswami Chettiar to make a gift of immovable joint family property to his wife.

issues.text: whether the gift deed in favour of Ammathayee was valid

anchor.surface_text: Further on the question whether the gift deed in favour of Ammathayee was valid, the trial court was of opinion that it was not competent for Rangaswami Chettiar to make a gift of immovable joint family property to his wife. The trial court therefore held the gift to be invalid and gave the plaintiff a decree for his half share in the property left by Rangaswami Chettiar, including the properties gifted to Ammathayee before his death.

issues.text: whether the heavy burden that lay on those who disputed the paternity of the plaintiff-respondent in view of s. 112 of the Indian Evidence Act... had been discharged

anchor.surface_text: On a consideration of the evidence, the High Court came to the conclusion that the heavy burden that lay on those who disputed the paternity of the plaintiff-respondent in view of s. 112 of the Indian Evidence Act, No. 1 of 1872, had not been discharged in this case

issues.text: whether the High Court was in error in holding on the basis of s. 112 of the Evidence Act that the paternity of the plaintiff-respondent had been proved

anchor.surface_text: It is also urged that the High Court was in error in holding on the basis of s. 112 of the Evidence Act that the paternity of the plaintiff-respondent had been proved. We are of opinion that there is no force in this contention.

arguments.claim: Hindu law permits reasonable gifts of movable ancestral property out of affection but restricts immovable to pious purposes

anchor.surface_text: Hindu law on the question of gifts of ancestral property is well-settled. So far as movable ancestral property is companycerned, a gift out of affection may be made to a wife, to a daughter and even to a son, provided the gift is within reasonable limits.

arguments.claim: Pious purposes do not include gift to wife out of affection or to fulfill father-in-law's promise for daughter-in-law

anchor.surface_text: A Hindu father or any other managing member has power to make a gift of ancestral immovable property within reasonable limits for pious purposes,  see Mullas Hindu Law, 13th Edn. para 226 p. 252 .

arguments.court_reasoning: No authority for extension to wife or daughter-in-law; distinguishes daughter cases

arguments.claim: Stridhan gifts from father-in-law to daughter-in-law do not include ancestral immovable property; harmonious construction
arguments.court_reasoning: Reconciles stridhan rule with prohibition on ancestral gifts

holdings.text: the plaintiff-respondent is the legitimate son of Rangaswami Chettiar

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore no hesitation in agreeing with the High Court, particularly taking into account the evidence of Lakshmiammal which has not been disbelieved by the High Court, that the appellants had completely failed to prove non- access of Rangaswami Chettiar to Lakshmiammal at any time when the plaintiff-respondent could have been begotten. In these circumstances there is no reason for us to interfere with the concurrent finding of fact as to the paternity of the plaintiff-respondent and we hold that he is the legitimate son of Rangaswami Chettiar.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings of lower courts upheld; appellants failed to discharge heavy burden under s.112 Evidence Act to prove non-access; notice by Rangaswami Chettiar insufficient; Lakshmiammal's evidence accepted; residences nearby

holdings.text: There is no force in the contention that the High Court erred in holding paternity proved on basis of s.112 Evidence Act

anchor.surface_text: It is also urged that the High Court was in error in holding on the basis of s. 112 of the Evidence Act that the paternity of the plaintiff-respondent had been proved. We are of opinion that there is no force in this contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Examined evidence including notice denying paternity but found insufficient to rebut conclusive presumption under s.112 requiring proof of non-access

holdings.text: Heavy burden under s.112 Evidence Act to prove non-access not discharged

anchor.surface_text: On a consideration of the evidence, the High Court came to the conclusion that the heavy burden that lay on those who disputed the paternity of the plaintiff-respondent in view of s. 112 of the Indian Evidence Act, No. 1 of 1872, had not been discharged in this case

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court agrees with High Court finding after review; no proof of non-access despite evidence adduced

holdings.text: Supreme Court would ordinarily not interfere with concurrent finding of fact on paternity

anchor.surface_text: there is a concurrent finding of the trial court as well as of the High Court that the plaintiffrespondent is the son of Rangaswami Chettiar. Ordinarily therefore this Court would not interfere with this concurrent finding of fact.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Principle of appellate restraint applied, though court examined evidence due to arguments raised

holdings.text: Gift deed of immovable ancestral property to wife out of affection invalid under Hindu law

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the donee-appellant that the gift in her favour by her husband of ancestral immovable property made out of affection should be upheld must therefore fail, for no such gift is permitted under Hindu Law insofar as immovable ancestral property is concerned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hindu law well-settled: gifts of movable ancestral property allowed within reasonable limits out of affection, but immovable ancestral property power circumscribed; only for pious purposes

holdings.text: Gift of ancestral immovable property not valid to fulfill father-in-law's promise at time of marriage as not pious purpose
holdings.reasoning_summary: Pious purposes limited to charity/religious or antenuptial promise to daughter; no authority for extension to wife or daughter-in-law via father-in-law's wish; father-in-law himself incompetent

holdings.text: No warrant in Hindu law for father-in-law to gift ancestral immovable property to daughter-in-law at marriage
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished from gifts to daughter fulfilling antenuptial promise; daughter-in-law becomes family member entitled in some cases; stridhan gifts reconciled as not extending to ancestral immovable

precedents.citation: Kamala Devi v. Bachu Lal Gupta

anchor.surface_text: But this Court has extended the meaning of pious purposes to cases where a Hindu father makes a gift within reasonable limits of immovable ancestral property to his daughter in fulfilment of an antenuptial promise made on the occasion of the settlement of the terms of her marriage, and the same can also be done by the mother in case the father is dead see Kamala Devi v. Bachu Lal Gupta.  1

precedents.case_name: Kamala Devi v Bachu Lal Gupta
precedents.cited_proposition: Hindu father can make gift of immovable ancestral property within reasonable limits to daughter in fulfilment of antenuptial promise for pious purposes
precedents.cited_holding: gift to daughter in fulfilment of antenuptial promise is pious purpose

precedents.citation: Guramma Bhratar Chanbassappa Deshmukh v. Malappa

anchor.surface_text: In Guramma Bhratar Chanbassappa Deshmukh v. Malappa,  2  it was observed by this Court that the Hindu law texts companyferred a right upon a daughter or a sister, as the case may be, to have a share in the family property at the time of partition. The right was lost by efflux of time. But it became crystallized into a moral obligation. The father or his representative can make a valid gift by way of reasonable provision for the maintenance of the daughter

precedents.case_name: Guramma Bhratar Chanbassappa Deshmukh v Malappa
precedents.cited_proposition: Father or representative can make valid gift of reasonable immovable ancestral property for maintenance of daughter or sister as moral obligation from ancient right
precedents.cited_holding: moral obligation allows reasonable gift for daughter's maintenance at any time

anchor.surface_text: The appeal therefore fails and is hereby dismissed with costs to to the plaintiff-respondent.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed upholding concurrent findings that plaintiff is legitimate son of Rangaswami Chettiar entitled to half share in joint family properties and that gift deed to Ammathayee is invalid.
directions: Appeal fails as against Natarajan Chettiar (respondent No. 3) who will get his costs from the appellants but no hearing fee.

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore no hesitation in agreeing with the High Court, particularly taking into account the evidence of Lakshmiammal which has not been disbelieved by the High Court, that the appellants had completely failed to prove non- access of Rangaswami Chettiar to Lakshmiammal at any time when the plaintiff-respondent could have been begotten. In these circumstances there is no reason for us to interfere with the concurrent finding of fact as to the paternity of the plaintiff-respondent and we hold that he is the legitimate son of Rangaswami Chettiar.
